meta.title: Project Hail Mary: The Adventure
meta.author: Interactive Adaptation
meta.description: An interactive text adventure based on Andy Weir's Project Hail Mary. Wake from a coma on an interstellar spaceship, befriend an alien engineer, and make the ultimate sacrifice to save two worlds from extinction.

coma_bay.name: Coma Bay
coma_bay.description: A sterile medical bay with three coma pods. Bright fluorescent lights buzz overhead. Medical equipment lines the walls. Two of the pods contain dead crew members.

ship_corridor.name: Ship Corridor
ship_corridor.description: A long, cylindrical corridor connecting the Hail Mary's compartments. Doors branch off in several directions, each marked with icons.

laboratory.name: Laboratory
laboratory.description: A well-equipped science lab with microscopes, spectrometers, centrifuges, and sample storage. Everything a biologist could need to study alien life forms.

control_room.name: Control Room
control_room.description: The ship's bridge. Multiple screens display navigation data, system status, and sensor readings. A pilot's chair faces the main viewport showing the stars.

storage_bay.name: Storage Bay
storage_bay.description: A large cargo hold packed with supplies, equipment, EVA suits, and scientific instruments. Everything is meticulously labeled and organized.

engine_room.name: Engine Room
engine_room.description: The spin drive dominates this space — a massive arrangement of chambers, pipes, and magnetic containment. The Astrophage fuel tank glows faintly amber.

airlock.name: Airlock
airlock.description: The EVA preparation chamber. Suit storage racks line the walls. The outer door leads to the void of space.

xenonite_tunnel.name: Xenonite Tunnel
xenonite_tunnel.description: A pressurized tunnel made of ultra-strong xenonite, connecting the Hail Mary to Rocky's ship. One side has Earth atmosphere, the other Eridian. A transparent barrier allows you to see and communicate with Rocky.

eridian_ship.name: Eridian Ship (Blip-A)
eridian_ship.description: Rocky's vessel. Viewed through the xenonite barrier, it's a world of textured surfaces and vibration-based interfaces. No screens — Eridians are blind to light. The atmosphere is ammonia at 29 times Earth pressure.

earth_university.name: Earth - University (Flashback)
earth_university.description: A memory of Grace's university classroom and lab. Posters of the periodic table and solar system decorate the walls. Students' projects line the shelves.

stratt_office.name: Stratt's Office (Flashback)
stratt_office.description: Eva Stratt's austere office at Hail Mary Project HQ. Maps, charts, and personnel files cover every surface. This woman controls humanity's last hope.

launch_facility.name: Launch Facility (Flashback)
launch_facility.description: A massive hangar where the Hail Mary is being assembled. Engineers from every nation work around the clock. The rocket towers above, pointed at the stars.

adrian_orbit.name: Adrian Orbit
adrian_orbit.description: Orbit around Adrian, the fourth planet of the Tau Ceti system. The planet's atmosphere shimmers below — a potential source of answers about Astrophage.

adrian_atmosphere.name: Adrian Atmosphere
adrian_atmosphere.description: Data streams in from the beetle probe descending through Adrian's thick atmosphere. The readings are extraordinary.

tau_ceti_space.name: Tau Ceti Space
tau_ceti_space.description: The void around Tau Ceti star. The yellow sun blazes in the viewport. Somewhere in this system lies the answer to saving Earth.

breeding_lab.name: Breeding Lab
breeding_lab.description: A section of the laboratory converted for Taumoeba breeding experiments. Rows of culture dishes, incubators set to various temperatures, and monitoring equipment fill every surface.

erid_surface.name: Erid Surface
erid_surface.description: The surface of Rocky's home world. Amber clouds churn overhead, lightning storms crackle across the horizon. Vast underground structures stretch beneath the hostile surface.

earth_return_orbit.name: Earth Return Orbit
earth_return_orbit.description: Earth hangs in the viewport — blue, white, and green. The most beautiful sight in the universe. Home.

rocky.name: Rocky
rocky.description: An Eridian engineer — a spider-like alien with five eyes, a rocky exoskeleton, and five legs/arms. Communicates through musical tones. Brilliant, loyal, enthusiastic. Speaks in distinctive patterns: 'Is good!', 'Amaze!', 'You are smart!'

stratt.name: Eva Stratt
stratt.description: Head of the Hail Mary Project. A ruthless pragmatist with unlimited international authority. Will do anything to save Earth, including forcing Grace onto the mission.

yao.name: Commander Yao
yao.description: Chinese taikonaut, the Hail Mary's commander. Compact, precise, competent. Died during coma transit. You remember him from flashbacks.

ilyukhina.name: Olesya Ilyukhina
ilyukhina.description: Russian cosmonaut and engineer. Tall, blonde, tough, and funny. Once repaired the ISS with duct tape and a pen cap. Died during coma transit.

dubois.name: Dr. Dubois
dubois.description: A scientist on the Astrophage research team. Originally selected for the Hail Mary crew before Grace replaced him.

dimitri.name: Dimitri
dimitri.description: Russian engineer who helped design the Hail Mary's systems. Appears in flashbacks.

leclerc.name: Dr. Leclerc
leclerc.description: A member of the Astrophage research team. Appears in flashback sequences.

steve.name: Steve Hatch
steve.description: Grace's friend and fellow teacher back on Earth. Appears in memory fragments.

bob.name: Bob (Beetle Probe)
bob.description: An unmanned probe launched to gather atmospheric data from planet Adrian.

grace_memory.name: Grace (Memory)
grace_memory.description: Grace's past self, appearing in flashback sequences. A scared but principled science teacher who said yes when humanity needed him.

lab_notebook.name: Lab Notebook
lab_notebook.description: Your research notes on Astrophage biology and behavior. Essential for experiments.

astrophage_sample.name: Astrophage Sample
astrophage_sample.description: A sealed container of living Astrophage organisms. They glow faintly amber with stored energy.

taumoeba_sample.name: Taumoeba Sample
taumoeba_sample.description: A culture of Taumoeba — organisms that eat Astrophage. Humanity's best hope.

eva_suit.name: EVA Suit
eva_suit.description: A custom-designed spacewalk suit with integrated life support, magnetic boots, and HUD.

xenonite_sheet.name: Xenonite Sheet
xenonite_sheet.description: A sheet of ultra-strong Eridian material. Can be shaped and bonded to repair Rocky's hull.

translator_device.name: Translator Device
translator_device.description: A musical-tone translator that converts between human speech and Eridian chords.

beetle_probe.name: Beetle Probe
beetle_probe.description: A small unmanned atmospheric sampling probe designed for planetary descent.

star_map.name: Star Map
star_map.description: A printed navigation chart of the Tau Ceti system with Astrophage concentrations marked.

rocky_gift.name: Rocky's Gift
rocky_gift.description: An intricately carved xenonite figurine from Rocky. On Erid, shaped stone given to closest friends means 'I trust you with my life.'

survival_rations.name: Survival Rations
survival_rations.description: High-calorie ration bars. They taste like cardboard wrapped in disappointment, but they keep you alive.

medical_kit.name: Medical Kit
medical_kit.description: Bandages, antiseptic, painkillers, antibiotics, and medications you need a pharmacy degree to identify.

tape_measure.name: Tape Measure
tape_measure.description: A retractable tape measure — your improvised first-contact communication tool with Rocky.

spectrometer.name: Spectrometer
spectrometer.description: A handheld spectrometer for analyzing the chemical composition of samples.

nitrogen_tank.name: Nitrogen Tank
nitrogen_tank.description: A tank of compressed nitrogen. Essential for replenishing Rocky's atmosphere after the leak.

coma_log.name: Coma Recovery Log
coma_log.description: Medical records from your coma recovery. Details the years-long transit and your crewmates' deaths.

fuel_cell.name: Fuel Cell
fuel_cell.description: A portable Astrophage-powered fuel cell. Generates more electricity than you could ever need.

ship_computer.name: Ship Computer
ship_computer.description: The Hail Mary's onboard computer system. Contains mission data, navigation, and scientific databases.

coma_pods.name: Coma Pods
coma_pods.description: Three medical pods for induced coma during interstellar transit. Two contain the bodies of Commander Yao and Engineer Ilyukhina.

spin_drive.name: Spin Drive
spin_drive.description: The Astrophage-powered propulsion system. Feeds living organisms into a reaction chamber to produce thrust via directed IR light.

coma_awakening.title: Waking Up
coma_awakening.content:
You open your eyes. Everything is blinding white. Your body feels wrong — weak, atrophied, like you haven't moved in years. Because you haven't.

You're lying in some kind of medical pod. Tubes snake from your arms and chest. A robotic arm adjusts an IV drip. Two other pods sit nearby, their occupants still and silent. Monitors flatline.

You have no idea who you are. You have no idea where you are. Your mind is a blank slate, wiped clean by whatever happened. But your body knows one thing with absolute certainty: something is very, very wrong.

interactions.resultText: You're thin. Dangerously thin. Your arms are wasted, your legs barely functional. An IV line feeds nutrients directly into your bloodstream. According to the medical readout above your pod, you've been in a medically induced coma for... you blink... approximately four years. Four years.

You drag yourself to the nearest pod. Through the glass, you see a man — Asian, compact build, military bearing even in death. The readout says 'YAO, LI — COMMANDER.' The other pod contains a tall blonde woman. 'ILYUKHINA, OLESYA — ENGINEER.' Both flatlined. Both dead. You were three. Now you're one.

interactions.buttonText: Read the medical log on the wall display
interactions.resultText: A screen near the pods displays the Coma Recovery Log. It details everything: the induced coma protocol, the years of transit, the automated medical care. Your crewmates died from complications during year two. The ship's AI continued caring for your body, feeding you, exercising your muscles with electrical stimulation. It kept you alive. Barely.
On shaking legs, you make your way to the door. It slides open with a pneumatic hiss, revealing a corridor beyond. You're on a spaceship. That much is becoming clear. But where? And why?

interactions.buttonText: Open the coma pods to check on your crewmates
interactions.resultText: You press the release mechanism on Yao's pod. The glass lid hisses open. He looks peaceful — like he's sleeping. But the monitors confirm what you already know. You close your eyes and rest your hand on the pod's edge. Commander Yao. Engineer Ilyukhina. They gave their lives for this mission. You won't waste their sacrifice.

interactions.buttonText: Create a small memorial for Yao and Ilyukhina
interactions.resultText: You find a marker and write their names on the wall above the pods, along with their ranks and nationalities. Commander Li Yao, CNSA. Engineer Olesya Ilyukhina, Roscosmos. You add the words: "They flew among the stars so Earth could live." It's not much. But it matters.

explore_coma_bay.title: First Steps
explore_coma_bay.content:
The corridor stretches before you, curving gently — you're inside a cylindrical spacecraft. Gravity pulls you down, which means the ship is either spinning or accelerating. Doors branch off in several directions, each marked with an icon: a flask, a steering wheel, a box, a gear.

Your legs are getting stronger with each step as muscles remember their purpose. Your mind, though, remains frustratingly blank. Who are you? Fragments surface and dissolve. A classroom. Students laughing. The periodic table. You were... a teacher?

interactions.resultText: The ship is well-maintained but clearly built for function over form. Handrails line the walls. Emergency lighting strips glow along the floor. Panels display system readouts in English, Chinese, and Russian. International cooperation built this vessel. Whatever the mission was, it was important enough for the whole world to contribute.

interactions.buttonText: Try to remember who you are
interactions.resultText: You squeeze your eyes shut and concentrate. Fragments flash by: a chalkboard, test tubes, a woman with cold eyes saying 'The mission needs you.' A name surfaces — Grace. Dr. Ryland Grace. You're a scientist. A molecular biologist. The rest is fog, but it's a start.
You push open the door marked with a flask icon and step into a fully equipped science laboratory.

interactions.buttonText: Head to the control room (wheel icon)
interactions.resultText: You follow the corridor to the door marked with a steering wheel and enter the ship's bridge.

interactions.buttonText: Think about what you saw in the lab
interactions.resultText: The Astrophage samples. Your own handwritten notes. This isn't just a mission — this is your life's work, crystallized in a floating laboratory twelve light-years from home. The pieces are connecting. You came here because you understood something about these organisms that no one else did. The question is: do you still?
You've seen the lab entrance and the control room door, but there's more to this ship. Time to explore every compartment — your survival might depend on knowing this vessel inside and out.

first_corridor.title: The Ship
first_corridor.content:
You've been exploring the Hail Mary for hours now — that's the ship's name, according to the plaques on the walls. Each compartment reveals more about your situation: you're on an interstellar vessel, powered by something called Astrophage, sent to the Tau Ceti star system.

The ship is designed for three crew members. Two are dead. You're the survivor, and you still can't remember why you're here. But with each room you explore, the fog lifts a little more.

interactions.resultText: You return to the lab, drawn by a scientist's instinct.
You head for the bridge to check navigation.
Time to see what supplies you have to work with.
You follow the corridor to the door marked with a gear icon. A deep hum reverberates through the walls as you approach.

discover_lab.title: The Laboratory
discover_lab.content:
The laboratory is a scientist's dream. Microscopes, spectrometers, centrifuges, incubators, sample storage — everything you could need for biological research. And it feels familiar. Your hands know where to reach before your mind tells them.

A sample container on the bench catches your eye. Inside, tiny amber-glowing organisms pulse with stored energy. Astrophage. The word surfaces from your broken memory with startling clarity. You know what these are. You know them intimately.

A wave of dizziness hits you and the lab dissolves. You're somewhere else. A classroom. You're standing at a whiteboard, marker in hand, explaining mitochondria to bored teenagers...

interactions.resultText: Under the microscope, Astrophage cells are roughly spherical, about 10 microns in diameter. They glow amber with stored energy — infrared, mostly. Each cell is a self-contained organism using an entirely alien biochemistry. No DNA, no RNA. They absorb light, convert it to mass via E=mc², and can release that energy as propulsion. They're living rocket fuel. And they're eating Earth's sun.

You find a notebook with your name on it. The handwriting is yours — detailed notes on Astrophage biology, experimental protocols, observations. Reading it feels like having a conversation with your past self. Each page brings back another fragment of memory.
A portable spectrometer sits in its charging dock. Useful for analyzing samples anywhere on the ship. You clip it to your belt.

The dizziness intensifies. The lab fades. You're somewhere else entirely — standing in front of a classroom of middle schoolers, chalk dust on your fingers, sunlight streaming through windows. Home. Earth. Before everything changed.

interactions.buttonText: Scan the Astrophage with your spectrometer
interactions.resultText: You point the handheld spectrometer at the sample container. The readings are extraordinary — absorption bands you've never seen before, emission spectra that don't match any known element. The Astrophage's biochemistry is genuinely alien. Not Earth life, not anything in your textbooks. Your spectrometer struggles to categorize what it's seeing. You save the raw data for later analysis.
You step back into the corridor. The lab has given you much to think about — Astrophage, your forgotten research, fragments of memory. But there's more of this ship to explore.

flashback_classroom.title: The Teacher
flashback_classroom.content:
The memory is vivid. You're Dr. Ryland Grace, and you teach science at a junior high school in San Francisco. Right now you're explaining cellular respiration to a room of thirteen-year-olds who couldn't care less. But you care. You love this.

'Energy conversion,' you say, tapping the whiteboard. 'Every living thing does it. Plants, animals, bacteria — they all convert one form of energy to another. It's the most fundamental thing about life.'

The classroom door opens. A woman walks in — sharp suit, sharp eyes, authority radiating from every pore. She introduces herself as Eva Stratt, and she needs to talk to you about something called Astrophage. Right now. It's a matter of planetary survival.

Your students look impressed. You're just confused.

interactions.resultText: 'Dr. Grace, you published a paper six years ago arguing that life doesn't require DNA as its basis. Everyone called you a crackpot.' She pauses. 'You were right. We've found an organism that proves it. It's called Astrophage, and it's eating our sun. You're one of three people on Earth who might understand how it works. I need you.'

interactions.buttonText: Look at your students one last time
interactions.resultText: Twenty-three faces stare at you and the intimidating woman. Marcus in the back row is trying to hide his phone. Abby in the front is scribbling notes furiously. You love these kids. You have no idea that you're about to leave them forever.

You excuse yourself from class and follow Stratt to a black car waiting outside. She tells you everything during the drive. Astrophage. The dimming sun. The end of the world. By the time you arrive at her temporary office, your life has changed forever.

flashback_recruitment.title: The Astrophage Project
flashback_recruitment.content:
Stratt's office is a war room. Maps, charts, orbital diagrams, and personnel files cover every surface. She has the authority of every government on Earth, and she wields it like a surgeon's scalpel.

'Astrophage is a microorganism,' she explains, pulling up data on a screen. 'It lives in the photosphere of the sun. It absorbs solar energy, converts it to mass, then migrates to Venus to breed. The energy it steals is measurable. Within thirty years, Earth's temperature will drop enough to trigger a global ice age. Within fifty, the surface will be uninhabitable.'

She shows you the Petrova line — the trail of infrared light connecting the sun to Venus, created by trillions of Astrophage in transit. Beautiful and terrifying.

'Every star in our neighborhood is affected. Except one: Tau Ceti. Something there naturally fights Astrophage. We're building a ship to find it. And I need scientists who understand alien biology.'

interactions.resultText: 'The ship is called the Hail Mary,' Stratt says. 'Three crew members. Four-year transit each way in induced coma. When you arrive at Tau Ceti, you find whatever is killing Astrophage there, and you bring it home. Simple.' She pauses. 'The coma survival rate is about 50%. This is likely a one-way trip. I won't lie to you about that.'

interactions.buttonText: Ask how she has this much power
interactions.resultText: 'The UN gave me emergency authority. Every nation on Earth agreed — when the alternative is extinction, bureaucracy becomes optional. I can commandeer any resource, draft any person, override any government. It's the most power any single human has ever held.' She meets your eyes. 'And I hate every second of it.'

interactions.buttonText: The memory fades... return to the present
interactions.resultText: The flashback dissolves like smoke. You're back on the Hail Mary, standing in the laboratory. Stratt. The mission. Astrophage. It's coming back to you now, piece by piece. You're here to save the world. And your two crewmates died trying.

control_room_discovery.title: Twelve Light-Years from Home
control_room_discovery.content:
The control room takes your breath away. A wide viewport dominates one wall, filled with stars — but not the stars you know. No Big Dipper, no Orion, no familiar constellations. These are alien skies.

The navigation display confirms your worst suspicion: you are in the Tau Ceti system, approximately 11.9 light-years from Earth. The ship has been decelerating for months. Arrival is imminent.

You sink into the pilot's chair. You're alone on a spaceship, in another star system, with a mission to save humanity. Your crewmates — the commander and engineer who were supposed to handle flying and repairs — are dead. It's just you. A biology teacher from San Francisco.

interactions.resultText: The nav display shows your position: approaching Tau Ceti from the direction of Sol. The deceleration burn will bring you into orbit around the system's fourth planet, designated 'Adrian.' From there, you'll survey the system for the Astrophage-fighting agent. The fuel gauge makes you nervous — you've burned through a lot of Astrophage getting here.

The mission database fills in the remaining gaps in your memory. The Hail Mary project: an international effort to send a three-person crew to Tau Ceti. Objective: find what's protecting Tau Ceti from Astrophage and bring it back to Earth. Timeline: critical. Humanity has maybe 30 years before the effects become catastrophic.

interactions.buttonText: Head to the lab to study Astrophage more closely
interactions.resultText: Armed with mission context, you head back to the laboratory with renewed purpose. Time to understand your enemy.

interactions.buttonText: Check the storage bay for supplies
interactions.resultText: Before diving into research, you want to know what resources you have available.

A persistent alarm has been pinging since you entered the control room — a proximity warning for the Tau Ceti system. You find the control and silence it. The sudden quiet is almost unsettling. For the first time, you can hear the ship's background hum — the life support, the spin drive, the soft vibration of a vessel hurtling through space at impossible speed.

You initiate a comprehensive diagnostic sweep. The ship computer shifts into high-performance mode — every screen fills with scrolling data. Hull integrity: 98%. Life support: nominal. Fuel: concerning. Navigation: on course. The computer will take several minutes to complete the full sweep, but the preliminary results are reassuring. The Hail Mary is in good shape, all things considered.
You leave the control room, mind reeling from the navigation data. Twelve light-years from Earth. The corridor stretches before you — there's more to explore.

astrophage_revelation.title: Understanding the Enemy
astrophage_revelation.content:
Back in the lab with your memory returning, the Astrophage samples take on new significance. This is an alien life form — genuine extraterrestrial biology — operating on principles that rewrite the textbooks. It absorbs light, stores energy by increasing its own mass (E=mc²), and uses that stored mass-energy for propulsion. It's a living rocket engine.

You have enough samples for detailed study, but your time before Tau Ceti arrival is limited. You need to focus your research: the biological mechanisms — how Astrophage reproduces, metabolizes, and what might kill it — or the energy properties — how it stores and releases energy, how the spin drive harnesses it, and how to manage your dwindling fuel.

interactions.resultText: Under high magnification, Astrophage cells are spherical, about 10 microns in diameter, glowing with faint amber light. Each is self-contained: no DNA, no RNA, entirely alien biochemistry. Heat, cold, radiation — nothing kills them. Whatever fights them at Tau Ceti must be something remarkable.
You transfer Astrophage into a sealed portable container. Having samples on hand could prove useful for experiments elsewhere on the ship.

interactions.buttonText: Focus on Astrophage biology and reproduction
interactions.resultText: You spend hours studying Astrophage reproduction — alien mitosis where each daughter cell carries half the parent's stored energy. The reproductive cycle is tied to temperature: they breed near Venus, ride the solar wind back to the sun. Understanding this cycle is key. If you can find something that disrupts reproduction, you can save Earth's sun. You document everything, building a biological profile of humanity's greatest threat.

interactions.buttonText: Focus on Astrophage energy properties and propulsion
interactions.resultText: You dive into energy characteristics. The numbers are staggering: a single gram stores the energy of 20 kilograms of rocket fuel. The spin drive directs Astrophage's energy release as thrust — tiny living organisms as propellant. You map absorption and release curves, calculating fuel needs for various Tau Ceti maneuvers. Practical knowledge that could save your life.

interactions.buttonText: Apply your advanced knowledge to decode the Astrophage genome
interactions.resultText: Your accumulated scientific knowledge clicks into place. You see patterns others would miss — the Astrophage's energy conversion isn't just chemistry, it's quantum biology. Each cell maintains a superposition state during photon absorption. It's beautiful. Terrifying, but beautiful. You document everything, filling pages with equations and diagrams.
Head still buzzing with Astrophage data, you step back into the main corridor. You could check on other parts of the ship before committing to a research focus.

storage_exploration.title: The Cargo Hold
storage_exploration.content:
The storage bay is packed floor to ceiling with carefully organized cargo. Crates of freeze-dried food, medical supplies, spare parts, scientific equipment, EVA suits, and things you don't immediately recognize. Everything is labeled and catalogued.

A quick inventory tells you that you have enough food for several years — the original mission accounted for three crew, so your solo status triples your supply. Silver lining to the 'everyone else is dead' situation. You try not to think about that too hard.

interactions.resultText: You pull an EVA suit from its rack — lighter and more flexible than anything NASA produced, with integrated life support and magnetic boots. Having a spacesuit handy seems like basic common sense when you're alone in deep space.
High-calorie ration bars. They taste like cardboard wrapped in disappointment, but they'll keep you going.
Bandages, antiseptic, painkillers, antibiotics. With no doctor on board — well, you're a doctor, but not that kind — this could prove essential.

The manifest lists everything: supplies for three crew for four years, plus spectrometers, sample containers, breeding chambers, a machine shop, and a section labeled 'CONTINGENCY SUPPLIES' with items you'd rather not think about.
Supplies secured. Now you want to see what's pushing this ship.
You leave the storage bay, pockets heavier with supplies. The corridor hums around you — plenty more to see on this ship.

engine_room_visit.title: The Spin Drive
engine_room_visit.content:
The engine room is a cathedral of engineering. The spin drive dominates the space — a complex arrangement of chambers, pipes, and magnetic containment that takes up most of the room. At its heart: the Astrophage fuel tank, glowing faintly amber.

The drive works by feeding Astrophage into a reaction chamber where the organisms release their stored energy as a stream of IR light, propelling the ship. It's elegant, terrifying, and entirely dependent on a living organism humanity barely understands.

The fuel gauges make you nervous. You've used a lot of Astrophage getting here. Getting home will be... a problem for later.

interactions.resultText: A masterpiece of engineering. Astrophage cells are fed into a stimulation chamber where tuned IR light triggers energy release. A few kilograms can accelerate the ship for days. The efficiency is mind-boggling.

The readings are concerning. Enough for orbital maneuvers at Tau Ceti and life support, but a return trip at the same acceleration? The math doesn't work. Unless you find more Astrophage or become much more efficient, this might be a one-way trip.
A self-contained unit powered by a tiny amount of Astrophage. Produces more electricity than you'd ever need for handheld equipment.
Standing in the engine room triggers something. You remember a much larger engine room — on Earth, during construction. Two people beside you, laughing. The memory pulls you in...

interactions.buttonText: Recalibrate the spin drive for better fuel efficiency
interactions.resultText: Your engineering knowledge is solid enough to attempt something risky. You access the drive's magnetic containment parameters and adjust the reaction chamber geometry. The fuel consumption rate drops by 3%. Doesn't sound like much, but over interstellar distances, that's millions of kilometers of extra range.

interactions.buttonText: Touch the reaction chamber's control panel
interactions.resultText: You reach for the reaction chamber controls and accidentally trigger a diagnostic burst. The spin drive roars to life for a fraction of a second — pure white light fills the room, the temperature spikes, and alarms blare. You stumble backward as emergency systems kick in. The drive shuts down automatically, but your heart is pounding. Note to self: don't touch things in the engine room.
You back away from the spin drive carefully and return to the corridor. The engine room's heat fades behind you.

flashback_crew_selection.title: The Crew
flashback_crew_selection.content:
The memory blooms. A massive hangar at a launch facility in China. The Hail Mary is being assembled — a tower of engineering ambition. And beside you stand your crewmates.

Commander Yao Li: compact, precise, radiating quiet competence. A Chinese taikonaut who speaks four languages and has logged more hours in space than most astronauts dream of. He shakes your hand: 'I've read your Astrophage papers. Brilliant work.'

Olesya Ilyukhina: tall, blonde, Russian, and terrifying in the best way. A cosmonaut who once manually repaired a coolant leak on the ISS using duct tape and a pen cap. She looks at you appraisingly: 'You don't look like someone who saves the world.' Then she grins. 'Neither do I. We'll get along.'

interactions.resultText: 'Transit time is approximately four years each way,' Yao explains calmly. 'We sleep through it in coma pods. The ship handles navigation during transit. When we arrive, we wake up, do the science, and come home.' He pauses. 'The coma survival rate is... not a hundred percent. But the alternative is watching everyone freeze to death. So.'

'The spin drive is beautiful,' Ilyukhina says, gazing at the engine assembly. 'I've worked on every propulsion system humans have built, and this is something else.' She lowers her voice. 'Don't die in the coma, okay? I need someone to argue with.'

interactions.buttonText: Watch the Hail Mary being built
interactions.resultText: Chinese engineering, American computers, Russian life support, European instruments. Every nation contributed. Built in eighteen months — a decade's work done in one and a half years because Stratt cut through every obstacle. Thousands of engineers building humanity's last hope.

interactions.buttonText: The memory fades... return to the present
interactions.resultText: Yao and Ilyukhina dissolve, and you're back in the engine room. Those two brave people are dead upstairs. Their part of the mission — flying, engineering — now falls to you as well. You swallow hard and head for the control room.

mission_clarity.title: Mission Clarity
mission_clarity.content:
Back in the control room, you lay it all out. The pieces of your shattered memory have formed a picture — terrifying and strangely motivating.

Astrophage is eating the sun. Within decades, Earth freezes. Every nearby star is affected except Tau Ceti, meaning something there naturally fights Astrophage. You're on the Hail Mary, sent to find that defense and bring it home. Your crewmates died during transit. You're alone, twelve light-years from Earth.

The mission is simple: find what's protecting Tau Ceti. The execution is anything but. Limited fuel, limited time, zero backup. But you're a scientist, and this is the biggest scientific question in history. Eight billion people are counting on you — they just don't know it.

interactions.resultText: Sensors paint an increasingly detailed picture of Tau Ceti: one star, several rocky planets, asteroid belts. Astrophage is present but in much lower concentrations than around Sol. Something keeps it in check. The sensors also detect something unexpected: a faint, regular signal that doesn't match any natural phenomenon.

The plan calls for orbiting the fourth planet ('Adrian'), surveying the system, identifying the Astrophage-fighting agent, collecting samples, and beginning the return. Written for three crew. You'll do it all yourself.

interactions.buttonText: Print a star map of the Tau Ceti system
interactions.resultText: You print a detailed map with Astrophage concentrations and the mysterious signal marked. Old-school science. Your students would be proud.
You strap in and begin the arrival sequence. Through the cameras, Tau Ceti grows brighter — a yellowish star against the void. Whatever answers await you, you're about to find them.

The diagnostic sweep has finished. The full report reveals details you missed: micro-fractures in hull panel 17B, a slow coolant leak in the life support scrubber, and slightly degraded solar panel efficiency. Nothing critical, but good to know. You file the data and return the computer to normal operating mode.

interactions.buttonText: Head back to the lab with new understanding
interactions.resultText: Now that you understand the full mission, the lab equipment takes on new meaning. Every instrument was chosen for the task of finding what kills Astrophage at Tau Ceti. Time to look at everything with fresh eyes.

interactions.buttonText: Check the engines before Tau Ceti arrival
interactions.resultText: Before the critical phase of the mission begins, you should make sure the spin drive is in good shape. You head down the corridor to the engine room.

tau_ceti_arrival.title: Tau Ceti
tau_ceti_arrival.content:
The deceleration burn is complete. The Hail Mary settles into a survey orbit, and Tau Ceti blazes in the viewport — a yellow star remarkably similar to Earth's sun, yet somehow protected from the Astrophage plague.

Sensor data floods in. The system has several rocky planets, one in the habitable zone (Adrian), and scattered asteroid belts. Astrophage is present but at a fraction of the density around Sol. Something here is keeping it in check.

You're the first human to see another star system up close. The magnitude of that hits you like a wave. Then you get to work.

interactions.resultText: The scan reveals Astrophage concentrations are highest near the star and decrease sharply near the orbit of Adrian. Something on or near Adrian is destroying Astrophage. That's your target. You also note an unusual infrared signature near the star — too regular to be natural.

The deceleration burn used a significant portion of your remaining Astrophage. You have enough for orbital maneuvers and life support, but the return trip calculation is grim. You'll need to be very efficient or find additional fuel.
That irregular infrared signature bothers you. Natural phenomena don't produce regular patterns. You adjust sensors for a closer look.

detect_anomaly.title: The Signal
detect_anomaly.content:
You're in the control room, fine-tuning the sensors, when you see it. The anomalous signal resolves into something unmistakable: a regular, repeating pattern of infrared emissions. Not natural. Not from your ship.

There's something else in this system. Something that produces energy in a controlled, deliberate pattern.

Your hands shake as you refine the data. The signal source is moving — it's in an orbit similar to yours, approaching Tau Ceti from a different direction. It's decelerating, just like you did.

It's a ship. Someone else sent a ship to Tau Ceti. And it's heading right for you.

interactions.resultText: The ship — if that's what it is — produces Astrophage-spectrum infrared light. It's using an Astrophage-based propulsion system, just like yours. But the engineering is clearly different. The energy output patterns don't match any human design. This isn't from Earth. This is alien. You're looking at proof of extraterrestrial intelligence.

The computer plots the alien vessel's trajectory. It originated from the 40 Eridani system — a star about 16 light-years from Earth. Like your sun, 40 Eridani is being dimmed by Astrophage. This alien civilization sent their own mission to Tau Ceti for the same reason you did. You're not alone in this fight.

interactions.buttonText: Prepare for contact with the alien vessel
interactions.resultText: The alien ship is approaching rapidly. In hours, you'll be in visual range. You need to decide how to handle first contact with an extraterrestrial intelligence.

first_contact_approach.title: First Contact
first_contact_approach.content:
The alien vessel is close now. Through the telescope, you can see it: a roughly cylindrical ship, different from yours but clearly built for the same purpose — interstellar travel using Astrophage propulsion. It's beautiful in an alien way.

Your heart hammers. This is first contact. The most important moment in human history, and it's happening to a middle school science teacher floating alone in space.

You need a strategy. You could attempt active communication — broadcast signals, flash lights, try to establish common ground. Or you could take a defensive posture — observe from a distance, learn what you can before revealing yourself.

interactions.resultText: You broadcast on every frequency. You flash lights in prime number sequences — the universal language of mathematics. 1, 2, 3, 5, 7, 11... You repeat it over and over. For an agonizing hour, nothing happens. Then the alien ship responds. The same sequence, repeated back. Then extended: 13, 17, 19, 23. Your eyes fill with tears. They're intelligent. They're mathematical. They're talking to you.

interactions.buttonText: Take a defensive posture — observe from distance
interactions.resultText: You power down non-essential systems to reduce your signature and observe. The alien ship seems to be doing the same thing — cautiously watching you. After hours of mutual surveillance, the alien makes the first move: a simple burst of IR light in a prime number sequence. They're reaching out. You realize that waiting was pointless — in the vast emptiness of space, both ships have nothing to gain from conflict and everything to gain from cooperation. You respond with your own prime sequence.

The ship is roughly cylindrical with what appears to be a spin drive at one end. The hull is made of an unknown material — strong, dense, almost rock-like. The ship has no windows or viewports. Whoever built this either doesn't use visible light... or doesn't need to see.

meeting_rocky.title: Rocky
meeting_rocky.content:
The alien ship extends a tunnel — a tube of some incredibly strong material — and connects it to your airlock. The material is transparent, allowing you to see through it. On the other side: a different atmosphere, impossibly high pressure, and temperatures that would cook you instantly.

And then you see HIM.

The alien is about the size of a large dog, with a rocky exoskeleton, five legs that double as arms, and five eyes arranged around a central body. He moves with surprising grace, using his limbs to grip surfaces. He has no mouth that you can see.

He communicates in musical tones — chords and harmonies that carry meaning. Your first exchange takes hours of patient repetition. But eventually, through mathematics and tone matching, you establish a basic vocabulary.

His name, translated roughly, is Rocky. And he's an engineer.

interactions.resultText: Communication is painfully slow at first. Rocky speaks in musical chords — each tone carries meaning. You establish numbers first: holding up fingers, matching to tones. Then nouns: pointing at objects, trading words. 'Ship.' 'Star.' 'Light.' After hours, you can exchange simple ideas. Rocky's enthusiasm is infectious — every successful exchange is met with an excited trill that you're learning means 'Good! Good!'

Rocky is fascinating. His exoskeleton appears to be actual rock — silicate-based, evolved on a high-gravity, high-temperature world. His five eyes don't process visible light; they detect sound waves. Rocky is essentially blind to light but 'sees' through echolocation. This explains why his ship has no windows. His five limbs are incredibly dexterous — you watch him manipulate tools with a precision that puts human hands to shame.

interactions.buttonText: Use a tape measure to help communicate
interactions.resultText: Brilliantly, you grab a tape measure and extend it to various lengths, matching each to a number you say aloud. Rocky catches on immediately. The tape measure becomes your Rosetta Stone — a physical bridge between two languages built on completely different senses.
Over the next days, you and Rocky develop an increasingly sophisticated vocabulary. It's the most important linguistic work in history, performed by a schoolteacher and an alien engineer.

interactions.buttonText: Use the tape measure to establish units with Rocky
interactions.resultText: You hold up the tape measure and point at markings. Rocky watches — well, "listens" with his entire body since he perceives vibrations, not light. You tap out a rhythm: one centimeter, two centimeters, three. Rocky echoes with musical notes — ascending in pitch. A mapping forms. Your centimeters to his chords. In thirty minutes, you've established a shared system of measurement. Rocky is delighted. "Amaze! You are smart!"

interactions.buttonText: Head back to the lab to study what you've learned
interactions.resultText: You tear yourself away from the incredible encounter and head back through the tunnel to the Hail Mary. You need to process what just happened — an alien. A living, thinking, engineering alien. And he seems friendly.

building_communication.title: Building Bridges
building_communication.content:
Days pass. Your shared vocabulary grows from dozens of words to hundreds. Rocky is a gifted communicator — he remembers everything you teach him and uses context brilliantly to fill gaps.

You learn the basics: Rocky comes from a planet orbiting 40 Eridani. His people are called Eridians. They sent him to Tau Ceti for the same reason Earth sent you — Astrophage is dimming their star too. Rocky is an engineer, the best his world has to offer. His ship is called the 'Blip-A.'

You build a translator device — a simple program that maps your words to Rocky's musical tones and back. It's crude but functional. For the first time in history, two species from different stars are having a real conversation.

interactions.resultText: You wire together a speaker, microphone, and simple processor. It maps your English words to Rocky's musical tones and vice versa. The translations are rough but workable. Rocky tests it by saying what sounds like a chord progression. The translator outputs: 'Is good device. You are smart.' You grin.

'Same problem!' Rocky chords excitedly. 'Astrophage eat your star. Astrophage eat my star. Both come here to find answer. Is amazing!' He's right — two civilizations, separated by light-years, facing the same extinction-level threat, arriving at the same solution independently. If this isn't proof that the universe has a sense of humor, nothing is.

interactions.buttonText: Accept a sample of xenonite from Rocky
interactions.resultText: Rocky passes a sheet of the tunnel material through a pressure-equalized exchange port. He calls it 'xenonite' — an incredibly strong material his people use for construction. It's transparent, tough, and can be shaped. 'Gift!' Rocky chords. 'For science!'
Rocky offers to show you his ship — through the xenonite barrier, of course. His atmosphere would kill you in seconds.

interactions.buttonText: Have a deep philosophical conversation with Rocky
interactions.resultText: Your communication skills have reached a point where you and Rocky can discuss abstract concepts. You talk about the nature of consciousness, the meaning of friendship across species, the loneliness of deep space. Rocky reveals that Eridians have a concept of "soul-friend" — someone who understands you so completely that your thoughts vibrate in harmony. "You are soul-friend, Grace. Is rare. Is precious."

interactions.buttonText: Head to the lab for more equipment
interactions.resultText: Building a translator from scratch requires tools you left in the lab. You tell Rocky you'll be right back — as best you can with your limited shared vocabulary — and head through the tunnel to the Hail Mary.

rocky_introduction.title: The Blip-A
rocky_introduction.content:
Through the xenonite barrier, Rocky gives you a tour of his ship. It's nothing like the Hail Mary. No screens, no buttons — Eridians are blind to light. Every surface is textured, designed to be read by touch. Navigation is done by vibration.

Rocky explains his world: Erid orbits 40 Eridani, a star about 16 light-years from Earth. Eridians live underground in vast cavern cities, communicating through sound in an ammonia-nitrogen atmosphere at 29 times Earth's pressure. They evolved on a heavy, hot world with no concept of vision.

'I am only Eridian here,' Rocky says. 'My crew... did not survive transit.' His tone carries unmistakable grief. 'Same as yours.' You're both sole survivors. Both carrying the hopes of your entire species.

interactions.resultText: 'Eridians are old civilization,' Rocky chords. 'Very old. We build, we engineer, we make things. Is what we do. No art like humans — we have music instead. Everything is music. Our buildings sing. Our ships hum. Even our language is music.' He pauses. 'Is beautiful, my world. I hope you save it.'

Rocky's engineering is incredible. Different from human tech but equally sophisticated. Their materials science is actually more advanced — xenonite alone is stronger than anything humans have produced. But their electronics are primitive compared to yours. Different evolutionary paths led to different technological strengths. Together, you'd be formidable.
Rocky's grief for his lost crew triggers your own memories. You remember Stratt — the choices she made, the people she used, the ruthless calculus of planetary survival.

interactions.buttonText: Compare Eridian engineering to the Hail Mary's
interactions.resultText: Having explored your own ship thoroughly, you can appreciate the differences. Where the Hail Mary uses screens and switches, Rocky's ship uses textured surfaces and vibration panels — Eridians are blind. Where you have steel and aluminum, they have xenonite and materials you can't identify. The engineering philosophy is completely alien, yet the goals are identical: survive the void, reach the star, save your world.
You've seen enough of Rocky's ship to appreciate how different — and how similar — your two civilizations are. You head back through the tunnel toward the Hail Mary side.

flashback_stratt_power.title: The Weight of Authority
flashback_stratt_power.content:
The memory is sharp. Stratt's office, months before launch. She's on the phone, and what she's saying makes your blood run cold.

'I don't care about the environmental impact assessment. The factory produces components we need. Override the local government.' She hangs up and sees your expression. 'Don't look at me like that, Grace. I shut down a nature preserve to build a centrifuge factory. Somewhere, a rare species of frog lost its habitat. Meanwhile, if we fail, every species on Earth loses its habitat.'

She wasn't wrong. That was the terrible thing about Stratt — she was almost never wrong. She made monstrous decisions with clear-eyed certainty, and the math always backed her up. Sacrificing the few for the many, over and over, with a precision that was either admirable or sociopathic.

interactions.resultText: She forced a teenager to skip his last year of high school to work on navigation algorithms. She seized a pharmaceutical company's entire output for crew medication. She had a Russian general arrested when he tried to delay construction. Every decision was calculated, justified, and utterly devoid of mercy. The world gave her absolute power, and she used every ounce of it.

But there were moments. Late at night, when she thought no one was watching, you saw her staring at the mission survival statistics with tears in her eyes. She knew she was sending people to their deaths. She just believed it was necessary. 'I'll answer for everything I've done,' she told you once. 'After. If we survive.'
The memory fades. You're back with Rocky, who is patiently waiting. Stratt did what she had to do. Now it's your turn. Time to do the science that justifies all the sacrifice.

joint_research_begins.title: Joint Research
joint_research_begins.content:
With Rocky as your research partner, you begin the real work: finding what fights Astrophage at Tau Ceti. You share data freely — Rocky's sensors complement yours, and his engineering insights open new approaches.

The question is where to focus. You could study Astrophage reproduction to understand its vulnerabilities — if you know how it breeds, you might find what stops it. Or you could search directly for predators — organisms that naturally consume Astrophage, which would explain why Tau Ceti has less of it.

'Both good ideas,' Rocky chords. 'But time is limited. Which first?'

interactions.resultText: You set up experiments to observe Astrophage reproductive cycles under controlled conditions. The work is painstaking but revealing: Astrophage breeds in a very specific temperature range, and the daughter cells need time to build up energy reserves before they can divide again. This gives you a framework for understanding what could disrupt the cycle. Rocky contributes engineering solutions for the experimental chambers.

You deploy the Hail Mary's sensors to scan for biological activity in areas where Astrophage density drops. Rocky helps by cross-referencing his own sensor data. The pattern is clear: Astrophage concentrations drop sharply near planet Adrian. Something in Adrian's environment is destroying it. 'We need closer look,' Rocky chords. 'Send probe to planet.'

'On Erid, when we have big problem, we break into small problems,' Rocky says. 'Then solve small problems one by one. Is engineering approach.' He pauses. 'But you are scientist. Scientists see whole picture at once. Maybe your approach better here.' You appreciate his faith in you, even if you're not sure it's warranted.

interactions.buttonText: Give Rocky your Astrophage sample for Eridian analysis
interactions.resultText: You carefully pass the sealed Astrophage container through the xenonite tunnel's transfer mechanism. Rocky's dexterous arms grab it eagerly. He subjects the sample to Eridian instruments — things that measure vibration patterns, pressure responses, molecular density. Within hours, he's found details your spectrometer missed. Two minds, two civilizations, one problem. "Good good good!" Rocky chimes.

interactions.buttonText: Go discuss ideas with Rocky at the tunnel
interactions.resultText: Research is better with a partner. You head to the xenonite tunnel where Rocky is waiting, his musical tones already humming with excitement about your latest findings.

adrian_probe_launch.title: Beetle Probe
adrian_probe_launch.content:
You prepare to launch a probe toward planet Adrian — the world where Astrophage concentrations drop most dramatically. Something down there is fighting it.

The probe is small, unmanned, and designed for atmospheric sampling. Rocky dubs it 'Bob' in a chord that roughly translates to 'brave little explorer.' You've grown fond of Rocky's naming conventions.

The launch goes perfectly. Bob streaks toward Adrian's upper atmosphere, transmitting data as it descends. The planet is rocky, with a thick CO₂ atmosphere and surface temperatures around 200°C. Not hospitable by human standards, but life finds a way — you of all people know that.

interactions.resultText: You watch Bob's telemetry in real-time. Temperature: 200°C. Pressure: 85 atmospheres. CO₂ atmosphere with trace methane and water vapor. And then — buried in the spectrometric data — biological signatures. There's life on Adrian. Microbial, simple, but undeniably alive. And where there's life, there might be Astrophage predators.

'Life on Adrian!' Rocky practically sings. 'Is amazing! Two star systems, both with life. Universe is more alive than anyone thought!' His enthusiasm is infectious. 'But we need specific life — life that eats Astrophage. Must go deeper into atmosphere.'

interactions.buttonText: Direct the probe deeper into the atmosphere
interactions.resultText: You send commands to Bob, directing the probe deeper into Adrian's thick atmosphere. The signal quality degrades as pressure increases, but the data keeps coming.

adrian_atmosphere_descent.title: Discovery
adrian_atmosphere_descent.content:
Bob's final transmission, before the probe is crushed by Adrian's atmospheric pressure, contains the most important scientific data in history.

In the mid-atmosphere layer, where Astrophage concentration drops to near zero, the probe detected a second organism. Smaller than Astrophage, aggressive, and hungry. It feeds on Astrophage like a lion feeds on gazelle — consuming the energy-rich organisms with voracious efficiency.

You stare at the data, hands trembling. This is it. This is what protects Tau Ceti. A natural predator of Astrophage. A microorganism that eats the thing that's eating your sun.

You name it Taumoeba. And it might just save two worlds.

interactions.resultText: Taumoeba is carbon-based, roughly 2 microns in diameter. It attacks Astrophage by penetrating the cell membrane and consuming the stored energy from the inside. One Taumoeba can destroy dozens of Astrophage cells before dividing. It's incredibly efficient — evolution at its finest.

'Is answer!' Rocky's tones are pure joy. 'Taumoeba eats Astrophage! We bring Taumoeba to our stars, Astrophage dies, stars are saved!' He pauses. 'But we need live samples. Must go collect from Adrian atmosphere.' 'Already on it,' you say, grinning.

You and Rocky work together to design a sample collection system. Using your biology expertise and his engineering skill, you build a device that can capture and contain live Taumoeba from Adrian's atmosphere.

taumoeba_discovery.title: Taumoeba
taumoeba_discovery.content:
You have live Taumoeba in the lab. The collection mission was harrowing — a modified probe, descended into Adrian's atmosphere, captured samples, and returned. Rocky's engineering made it possible; your biology knowledge told you where to look.

Under the microscope, Taumoeba is remarkable. Each tiny organism is a dedicated Astrophage hunter, evolved over millions of years for this single purpose. You watch one attack an Astrophage cell — penetrating the membrane, consuming the stored energy, then dividing to produce two hungry offspring. It's beautiful.

interactions.resultText: Taumoeba thrives between 15 and 80 degrees Celsius. Needs CO₂, tolerates a range of pressures. Dies in vacuum, dies in pure oxygen. Like all life, it's particular about its environment.

interactions.buttonText: Prepare Taumoeba samples for further study
interactions.resultText: You carefully culture Taumoeba in several sealed containers, maintaining Adrian-like conditions. Having multiple samples means you can run parallel experiments.

'Taumoeba must work for Earth AND for Erid,' you say. 'Yes yes yes,' Rocky chords. 'Earth conditions and Erid conditions are different. Taumoeba maybe not like Erid conditions.' 'That's what I'm worried about.' 'We test! We experiment! We are scientists!' Rocky's confidence is reassuring.

interactions.buttonText: Continue research — but an alarm sounds from Rocky's ship
interactions.resultText: You're deep in analysis when a sharp alarm blares from the Eridian end of the tunnel. Rocky freezes, then scrambles toward the sound. 'Problem! Big problem! My ship! Leak!'

interactions.buttonText: Share your lab notebook with Rocky
interactions.resultText: You hold up your notebook pages to the xenonite barrier. Rocky can't see them — he's blind — but you read them aloud, and the translator converts your voice to Eridian chords. Rocky listens intently, occasionally interrupting with excited harmonics. He offers corrections, alternative hypotheses, new angles you hadn't considered. Collaboration across species lines. This is science at its finest.

interactions.buttonText: Rush to the tunnel to tell Rocky about the discovery
interactions.resultText: This is too big to keep to yourself. You race through the corridor to the xenonite tunnel. Rocky needs to know — you've found something that eats Astrophage. Both your worlds might be saved.

interactions.buttonText: Check the control room sensors for more data
interactions.resultText: The Taumoeba discovery raises new questions. You head to the control room to check sensor data — orbital patterns, atmospheric composition, anything that might help you understand these organisms better.

rocky_crisis.title: Nitrogen Emergency
rocky_crisis.content:
Rocky's ship is venting nitrogen. A micro-fracture in the hull is hemorrhaging gas into space. For a species that lives at 29 atmospheres, a pressure drop is catastrophic. Rocky could die.

'Leak in hull section seven,' Rocky chords, and you hear fear — something you've never heard from him before. 'Nitrogen leaving fast. Cannot reach from inside.'

The fracture is on the exterior, in a region bathed in heat from Rocky's environment. You need a plan. Fast.

interactions.buttonText: Suit up for immediate EVA repair
interactions.resultText: No time for debate. You grab your EVA suit and cycle through the airlock. You mag-boot along the hull to the fracture — a hairline crack venting gas. The heat is intense, your suit screaming warnings. You apply emergency sealant, layer after layer. 'Is working?!' Rocky chords desperately. 'Pressure stabilizing!' The sealant holds. You're drenched in sweat and shaking when you return, but Rocky is alive.

interactions.buttonText: Engineer a xenonite patch — a permanent fix
interactions.resultText: 'Rocky, don't panic. I have an idea.' You grab your xenonite sheet and fashion a patch shaped precisely to cover the fracture. Using Rocky's instructions and your ingenuity, you design a pressurized application system using spare nitrogen. The patch fuses with the hull material — a permanent repair. 'Pressure stable!' Rocky chords with relief. 'You save me! You are best friend!'

Rocky's sensors show the fracture location and rate of loss. At this rate, Rocky's ship drops below survivable pressure in four hours. The xenonite has fatigued from the interstellar journey. You have a window, but it's closing.
'Rocky. I will fix this. I promise.' A long pause. Then, quietly: 'I trust you, friend.' Those three words carry more weight than any engineering specification.

interactions.buttonText: Eat rations to keep your strength up
interactions.resultText: You tear open a ration bar and choke it down. Tastes like defeat, but the calories hit your bloodstream fast. Your hands stop shaking. You can focus now. Rocky needs you at your best.

Panic overrides reason. You race to the airlock and cycle it open without checking suit integrity, without running diagnostics, without telling Rocky. The void hits you like a wall of ice. Your suit — hastily donned — has a seal failure in the left glove. You feel the pressure drop, the cold seeping in. As your vision tunnels and the stars blur, you think of Earth, of your students, of Rocky's musical voice saying "Is okay, Grace." But it's not okay. It's the furthest thing from okay.

nitrogen_repair.title: Holding Together
nitrogen_repair.content:
The immediate crisis is over, but Rocky's nitrogen reserves are depleted. You rig a transfer line through the tunnel and pump nitrogen from your reserves into Rocky's ship, slowly restoring survivable pressure.

'You save my life, Grace,' Rocky says, relief in every chord.

'That's what friends are for,' you reply. And you mean it. Somewhere in the last few weeks, this alien rock-spider became the best friend you've ever had.

interactions.resultText: You monitor gauges as nitrogen flows to Rocky's ship. The process takes hours. By the end, Rocky is back to 29 atmospheres. Your own reserves are lower, but manageable.

interactions.buttonText: Grab a nitrogen tank from storage
interactions.resultText: You fetch a compressed nitrogen tank from the storage bay. This will help replenish Rocky's atmosphere.

interactions.buttonText: Talk to Rocky about what happened
interactions.resultText: 'On Erid, when someone saves your life, you owe a life-debt. Most sacred bond.' 'On Earth we just say you're welcome and buy each other a beer.' 'What is beer?' 'A drink that makes you temporarily stupid.' 'Why would you want to be stupid?' 'That's a fair question.'

interactions.buttonText: Rest after the ordeal — memories surface again
interactions.resultText: Exhausted, you collapse in your bunk. Sleep brings memories you've been avoiding. The launch. The moment everything changed.

interactions.buttonText: Treat your injuries with the medical kit
interactions.resultText: The EVA was brutal. Your hands are scraped raw, and you've got a nasty bruise on your shoulder from slamming against the hull. You crack open the medical kit — antiseptic, bandages, a mild painkiller. Within minutes you feel human again. Well, human-ish.

interactions.buttonText: Apply the xenonite sheet to seal the hull breach
interactions.resultText: You carefully shape the xenonite sheet over the breach in Rocky's hull. The material bonds perfectly — xenonite on xenonite, molecularly fusing into a seamless seal. The pressure readings stabilize. The leak stops. Rocky's ship is whole again. "Is good! Is good!" Rocky's musical tones ring with relief.

interactions.buttonText: Head to the lab — there's still research to do
interactions.resultText: The crisis is over, at least for now. Rocky's ship is stable. But the mission isn't done — Taumoeba still needs work. You head back through the corridor to the laboratory, exhausted but determined.

flashback_launch.title: The Last Choice
flashback_launch.content:
The memory is sharp and terrible. Launch day. Baikonur Cosmodrome. The Hail Mary stands on the pad, three hundred meters of humanity's last hope.

You were the backup. Dubois was suited up and ready. Yao and Ilyukhina were aboard. Three brave volunteers for a suicide mission.

But Stratt gave the nod to the medical team. They approached you with a syringe.

'I'm sorry, Dr. Grace,' Stratt said, not sounding sorry at all. 'The mission needs you. You understand the science better than Dubois.'

You tried to run. You didn't make it three steps.

interactions.resultText: The needle entered your arm and the world went soft. Your last thought before the coma wasn't of Earth or science. It was anger. Pure, helpless anger at Stratt for taking your choice away. You didn't volunteer to die. You were drafted.

Not cruel, not regretful. Just resolved. She'd done the calculation. Grace on the ship meant higher probability of success. Ethics didn't matter weighed against survival. The terrible part is she was probably right.

You jolt awake, heart pounding. The memory recedes but the feelings remain — guilt, anger, determination. Yao and Ilyukhina gave their lives. Stratt gave her soul. The least you can do is finish the job.

deepening_friendship.title: Friends Across the Stars
deepening_friendship.content:
In the days after the crisis, you and Rocky spend long hours at the tunnel, talking about everything and nothing. Words come easier now — thousands of shared terms, and Rocky has a gift for mimicry.

Rocky tells you about Eridian music — vast symphonies in underground concert halls, experienced through vibrations in every limb. You tell Rocky about sunsets and rainbows. Rocky is fascinated by color, a sense Eridians will never know.

'You see things I cannot,' Rocky chords wistfully. 'But I hear things you cannot. Together we experience more of the universe.'

Rocky presents you with a gift: a carved xenonite figurine. 'On Erid, shaped stone to closest friends means: I trust you with my life.'

interactions.resultText: The figurine is warm from Rocky's grip and surprisingly heavy, with intricate geometric patterns. It's the most precious thing you own. 'Thank you, Rocky. I will keep it always.' 'Is good! You are best friend. Best human friend. Only human friend. But still best!'

You describe oceans, forests, mountains, rain. Rocky listens raptly. 'Earth sounds beautiful. So much water! On Erid, water is rare and precious.' 'It is, when we're not busy messing it up.' 'All species mess up home world. Is tradition.'
'We have work-groups. Mine built the Blip-A. Thirty-one Eridians, years of work. They know I am not coming home. But if I send Taumoeba to Erid, they live. That is enough.'

interactions.buttonText: Return to the lab — work to do
interactions.resultText: The warmth lingers as you float back to the lab. Rocky is counting on you. Earth is counting on you. Erid is counting on you.

interactions.buttonText: Ask Rocky about the Eridian word for "home"
interactions.resultText: Rocky pauses — a long silence that, for an Eridian, means deep emotion. Then a complex chord fills the tunnel, layers of harmonics you've never heard before. "That sound mean home," Rocky says. "But also mean... the people who wait for you there. My children. Twenty-three of them. They wait for me, Grace. They wait." You realize Rocky has never spoken about his family before. He trusts you enough now to share his deepest fear.

interactions.buttonText: Head to the lab — back to work
interactions.resultText: As much as you enjoy Rocky's company, there's work to do. You say goodbye for now and head through the tunnel back to the Hail Mary's laboratory.

taumoeba_problem.title: The Erid Problem
taumoeba_problem.content:
The lab results hit like a punch. Taumoeba works beautifully in Earth-like solar conditions — consumes Astrophage eagerly, reproduces rapidly. The miracle cure humanity needs.

But when you simulate conditions around 40 Eridani — higher temperatures, different radiation, Erid's atmospheric composition — Taumoeba dies. Every sample. Every time.

Rocky takes the news in silence. For a creature who communicates in music, the silence is devastating.

'We will find a way,' you say. 'We are not done.'

interactions.buttonText: Modify the breeding approach — selectively evolve Taumoeba
interactions.resultText: Directed evolution: gradually expose cultures to increasingly Eridian conditions, selecting for survivors. Thousands of cultures, carefully managed, only the hardiest reproducing. 'Is like training,' Rocky chords hopefully. 'Make Taumoeba stronger, little by little.' 'Exactly. Evolution is the best engineer in the universe.'

interactions.buttonText: Test new environments — find conditions that work for both
interactions.resultText: Instead of changing Taumoeba, find conditions where it survives that also exist in the Eridian system. You systematically test every combination of temperature, pressure, atmosphere. Rocky provides data on every environment in 40 Eridani's system. After exhaustive testing, you find a narrow band. 'Is not perfect,' Rocky chords. 'But is possible.' 'Possible is all we need.'

interactions.buttonText: Analyze why Taumoeba dies in Eridian conditions
interactions.resultText: Cell membranes rupture at Eridian temperatures — they cook. Proteins denature, metabolic pathways collapse. But a small percentage of cells last slightly longer. Natural variation. If you can select for that variation...

'Rocky. We crossed interstellar space. We invented a shared language from scratch. We survived a nitrogen leak. A temperature problem will not beat us.' Quiet moment. Then: 'You are right. We are smart. We are determined. We will solve.' 'Damn right we will.'

interactions.buttonText: Doubt yourself — are you smart enough for this?
interactions.resultText: For a moment, the weight of it all crushes you. Two entire worlds depending on a junior-high science teacher. You stare at the Taumoeba cultures and wonder if a real scientist — Dubois, maybe, or Leclerc — would have figured this out already. Then you remember: those "real scientists" aren't here. You are. And self-pity won't save anyone. You roll up your sleeves.

breeding_experiments.title: Breeding Lab
breeding_experiments.content:
You convert a section of the laboratory into a dedicated breeding facility. Rows of culture dishes, incubators set to various temperatures, monitoring equipment — everything you need for the most important biology experiment in history.

The work is grueling. Thousands of Taumoeba cultures, each exposed to slightly different conditions, each monitored for survival. Most die. But some — a precious few — survive a little longer than the rest. You isolate those survivors, breed them, and push the next generation a little harder.

Rocky helps by maintaining the equipment and running calculations. He's not a biologist, but he's the best lab assistant you've ever had.

interactions.buttonText: Check the latest generation of cultures
interactions.resultText: Generation 47 shows promise. Survival time in Eridian conditions has increased from seconds to minutes. Still not enough, but the trend is clear. Evolution works — you just need to push it further. Rocky watches the data with rapt attention. 'Is working! Slow, but working!'

'Each generation stronger,' Rocky chords. 'Is beautiful. On Erid, we breed metal-eating bacteria for mining. Same principle. Patience and selection.' 'You breed bacteria for mining?' 'Is efficient! Bacteria work for free!' You can't argue with that logic.

The spectrometer reveals that surviving Taumoeba have slightly different cell membrane compositions — higher concentrations of heat-resistant proteins. Natural selection is doing its job, producing organisms better suited to Eridian temperatures.
Weeks of breeding have brought you to a crossroads. The next experiment could be the breakthrough — or a dead end.

interactions.buttonText: Scrap the current batch and start fresh
interactions.resultText: Sometimes the best science means admitting failure. You dispose of the current Taumoeba cultures — none of them are viable for Eridian conditions. You sterilize the equipment, prep fresh media, and start a new batch with different parameters. It feels like going backward, but you know better. Every failed experiment eliminates a possibility.

interactions.buttonText: Go to the main lab for fresh supplies
interactions.resultText: The breeding lab's supplies are running low. You head to the main laboratory for fresh culture media, clean glassware, and a change of scenery. Sometimes stepping away from a problem helps you see it clearly.

interactions.buttonText: Consult Rocky about the breeding problems
interactions.resultText: Two heads are better than one — even when one head is a five-eyed spider alien. You head to the xenonite tunnel to brainstorm with Rocky. His Eridian perspective might reveal something you're missing.

breakthrough_attempt.title: The Critical Experiment
breakthrough_attempt.content:
You've bred Taumoeba through hundreds of generations. The survivors can tolerate temperatures partway to Eridian conditions, but you've hit a plateau. Natural selection has taken you as far as it can with gradual pressure.

You need a breakthrough. You could take the conservative approach — continue gradual selection, accepting that it might take months more. Or you could try something radical — expose the cultures to extreme conditions all at once, hoping that a rare mutation survives where normal evolution stalls.

Rocky watches you deliberate. 'Both have risk,' he chords. 'What does your scientist instinct say?'

interactions.buttonText: Take the conservative approach — steady progress
interactions.resultText: Patience wins. You continue the gradual selection process, inching the temperature higher with each generation. It takes weeks more, but the results are undeniable — Taumoeba-82F, as you designate the final strain, can survive and reproduce in full Eridian conditions. It's not as vigorous as the Earth-adapted strain, but it works. 'Is enough!' Rocky chords. 'Taumoeba-82F will save Erid!'

interactions.buttonText: Try radical mutation — high risk, high reward
interactions.resultText: You blast the cultures with UV radiation and extreme temperatures simultaneously. 99.99% of the organisms die instantly. But in dish 7,812 — a single colony survives. One mutant, one freak of nature, that can withstand Eridian conditions. You culture it, test it, verify it. Taumoeba-R7812 not only survives in Eridian conditions — it thrives. 'Is miracle!' Rocky chords. 'You are genius!'

The plateau is caused by a fundamental limitation in Taumoeba's cell membrane. The proteins that provide heat resistance also reduce the organism's ability to penetrate Astrophage cells. There's a trade-off — and evolution can't optimize for both simultaneously without a lucky mutation.

interactions.buttonText: Trust your instincts — the answer is right there
interactions.resultText: It hits you like lightning. The Taumoeba breeding problem — it's not about temperature or pressure. It's about the magnetic field. Erid has a much stronger magnetic field than Earth, and Taumoeba orients its cellular machinery along magnetic field lines. You just need to add a magnetic component to the incubator. You scramble for equipment, hands shaking with excitement. This is it. This is the answer.

interactions.buttonText: Manually override the incubator's safety limits
interactions.resultText: You bypass the safety interlocks on the incubator to push the Taumoeba to extreme conditions. The containment field fluctuates — and fails. A burst of concentrated Astrophage energy floods the lab. The radiation is invisible but devastating. You feel warmth, then numbness, then nothing. Rocky's voice reaches you through the translator, frantic and musical, but the words dissolve into static. The lab goes dark.

taumoeba_success.title: Eureka
taumoeba_success.content:
You've done it. After weeks of painstaking work, you have a strain of Taumoeba that works in both Earth and Eridian conditions. It's not equally vigorous in both — the compromises of evolution mean it's slightly less efficient than the wild type — but it works. It consumes Astrophage in environments matching both solar systems.

Rocky is beside himself with joy. His musical chords fill the tunnel with what you can only describe as a symphony of gratitude. 'Grace! We save both worlds! Is best day! Best day ever!'

You allow yourself a moment of pure, uncomplicated happiness. Then the scientist in you gets back to work. You need to prepare samples for both Earth and Erid, calculate delivery methods, and plan the logistics of saving two civilizations.

interactions.buttonText: Prepare Taumoeba samples for both worlds
interactions.resultText: You culture massive quantities of the successful strain, dividing them into two batches: one optimized for deployment in Earth's solar environment, one for 40 Eridani. Each batch is packed in sealed, self-sustaining containers designed to survive the journey to their respective destinations.

'We did it, Rocky.' 'WE did it,' Rocky corrects. 'Human science and Eridian engineering. Together. Is how it should be.' He pauses. 'On Erid, when great thing is accomplished, we sing. I will sing for us.' What follows is the most beautiful thing you've ever heard — a cascading waterfall of harmonics that brings tears to your eyes. You don't understand the words, but you understand the feeling perfectly.

interactions.buttonText: Head to the control room — calculate the trip home
interactions.resultText: The celebration is brief. Now comes the hard part: getting the Taumoeba to where it needs to go. You head to the control room to crunch the numbers.

interactions.buttonText: Rush to tell Rocky the good news in person
interactions.resultText: You sprint through the corridor to the xenonite tunnel. Rocky needs to hear this face to face — well, face to whatever Eridians have. You've done it. Taumoeba works for both worlds.

fuel_calculation.title: The Math Doesn't Lie
fuel_calculation.content:
You run the numbers three times. Then a fourth. The answer doesn't change.

Between the two ships, there is only enough Astrophage fuel for ONE interstellar trip. Either the Hail Mary can return to Earth with Taumoeba for your sun, or Rocky's Blip-A can return to Erid with Taumoeba for his star. Not both.

The math is pitiless and absolute. The universe doesn't care about fairness.

You stare at the screen, the weight of two civilizations pressing down on your shoulders. Rocky doesn't know yet. You need to tell him. And then you need to make the hardest decision of your life.

interactions.resultText: You check every variable: remaining Astrophage in both ships, transit distances, deceleration requirements, life support reserves. The conclusion is inescapable. 11.9 light-years to Earth. 16.3 light-years to Erid. Combined fuel: enough for one trip of either distance, with minimal margin. Not both. Never both.

You explore every alternative. Mining Astrophage locally? Would take decades. Splitting fuel for two short trips? Neither ship would make it. Building more fuel? Impossible without infrastructure. The only option is to choose: Earth or Erid. One world gets its salvation delivered. The other has to wait and hope.
You float through the corridor to the xenonite tunnel. Rocky is there, still humming his celebration song. You hate that you're about to ruin it.

interactions.buttonText: Connect the portable fuel cell to the reserves
interactions.resultText: You hook the portable fuel cell into the main fuel system. It's not much — a drop in the ocean compared to what the spin drive needs — but every gram of Astrophage counts. The navigation computer recalculates. The numbers shift, barely. Still not enough for both trips.

interactions.buttonText: Go to the lab to think this through
