interactions.resultText: The numbers are bleak. You need to think. You head to the lab — your thinking place, the room where problems have solutions. Maybe if you look at it from a different angle...

interactions.buttonText: Go talk to Rocky before making any decisions
interactions.resultText: Before you decide anything, you need to talk to your friend. You walk slowly through the corridor to the xenonite tunnel. Rocky deserves to know the situation. Both of you deserve to face this together.

rocky_farewell_prep.title: The Goodbye
rocky_farewell_prep.content:
You tell Rocky the truth. He listens in silence — that terrible Eridian silence that means deep processing.

'Only one ship goes home,' he repeats.

'Only one.'

Rocky's response is immediate and absolute: 'You go home. Earth needs Taumoeba. I stay.'

'Rocky, no. Erid needs it too—'

'Earth has more people. Eight billion. Erid has two billion. Math is clear.' He pauses. 'Also, you are my friend. Friends do not let friends die.'

Your throat constricts. Rocky is willing to sacrifice his entire civilization for yours. Because of math. And friendship. The selflessness of it is staggering.

interactions.resultText: 'Rocky, I can't just leave Erid to die.' 'Is not your choice. Is my choice. I choose to save your world.' His voice carries a fierce certainty. 'Eridians are strong. Maybe we find other solution. But Earth cannot wait. You MUST go home, Grace.'

interactions.buttonText: Help Rocky prepare for his sacrifice
interactions.resultText: Rocky begins transferring Taumoeba samples to your ship, organizing his research notes, recording messages for his work-group on Erid. He works with quiet efficiency, as if preparing for a normal mission. But you can hear the sadness in his undertones — frequencies he doesn't know you've learned to detect.

You run every scenario again. Transfer fuel between ships? Already accounted for. Use the towing cable to haul both ships? Not enough thrust. Hibernate and wait for rescue? No one's coming. The math is final. One trip. One world saved directly. The other left to hope.

interactions.buttonText: Head to the control room — make the decision
interactions.resultText: Rocky is loading your ship with Taumoeba and supplies. Everything is prepared for you to go home. But as you float toward the control room, a thought gnaws at you. Is 'going home' really the right choice?

Rocky's musical tones are flat, muted. The translator renders his words precisely but you can hear the emotional absence underneath. "We solve problem. Is good," he says. But there's none of his usual enthusiasm. You realize you never invested enough in this friendship — always focused on the science, never on the being across the barrier. You wish you'd tried harder.

interactions.buttonText: Go back to the lab — run the numbers one more time
interactions.resultText: You can't accept this. There has to be another way. You head back to the lab, pulling up every dataset, every experiment, every scrap of data. There must be something you missed.

interactions.buttonText: Check the engine room — maybe there's a way to stretch the fuel
interactions.resultText: Desperation drives you to the engine room. You stare at the spin drive, willing it to be more efficient, willing the laws of physics to bend. The amber glow of the Astrophage fuel tank mocks you with its finite supply.

the_big_choice.title: The Decision
the_big_choice.content:
You sit in the pilot's chair. The course is laid in: Tau Ceti to Sol, 11.9 light-years, four years in coma. Taumoeba is loaded. You can go home.

But if you give your fuel to Rocky instead, HE can go home. Erid gets saved. You'll be stranded in Tau Ceti with a functioning ship but no way to reach Earth — but you can transmit the Taumoeba data by radio. It would take 12 years to arrive, and Earth would need to figure out how to breed it themselves, but it's possible.

Rocky would live. Erid would be saved directly. Earth would have a harder road, but a road nonetheless.

Or you go home. Earth gets saved immediately. Rocky stays behind and dies. Erid's two billion people face extinction.

This is the moment. This is why you're here.

interactions.buttonText: Return to Earth — save humanity directly
interactions.resultText: You choose Earth. Eight billion people. Your home. Your students. Logic dictates the greater number. You engage the navigation system and the course is locked. As the engines begin to hum, you float to the tunnel for one last goodbye. Rocky is waiting. 'Is right choice,' he chords softly. 'Go save your world, Grace.' You can barely speak. 'Goodbye, Rocky.' 'Goodbye, friend.'

interactions.buttonText: Give fuel to Rocky — save your friend and Erid
interactions.resultText: You open the fuel transfer valve. Astrophage begins flowing from the Hail Mary to the Blip-A. 'GRACE! What are you doing?!' Rocky's voice is a discordant shriek. 'NO! Stop! You are killing yourself!' You watch the fuel gauge drop. 'I'm saving my friend,' you say simply. 'Earth will get the data by radio. It'll take longer, but they'll figure it out. They're smart.' 'Grace...' 'Rocky, shut up. You're going home.'

interactions.buttonText: Review the calculations one more time
interactions.resultText: Earth path: 100% Taumoeba delivery, you survive (probably), Rocky and Erid die. Rocky path: transmit data to Earth (12-year delay, uncertain success), Rocky and Erid saved, you stranded but alive. The numbers are clear. The ethics are not.

"Grace. I know you think about this. Earth or Erid." Rocky's tones are impossibly soft. "I not ask you choose me. I ask you choose what make you... you. The Grace who teach children. The Grace who cross stars to help stranger. That Grace know what to do." He pauses. "Whatever you choose, you are good good good friend. Best friend. Always."

earth_path_1.title: Homeward Bound
earth_path_1.content:
The engines fire. The Hail Mary begins its long journey home. Through the rear cameras, you watch the xenonite tunnel separate, watch Rocky's ship grow smaller against the stars of Tau Ceti.

Rocky's last transmission arrives as a simple chord: 'Be happy, Grace.'

You set the coma system. In moments, you'll be asleep, and in four years, you'll wake up in Earth orbit with the cure for Astrophage. A hero. A savior.

But as the coma drugs take hold, your last conscious thought is of a spider-like alien with five eyes and a voice like music, watching your ship disappear into the void. Alone.

interactions.buttonText: Record a final message for Earth
interactions.resultText: You record everything: the Taumoeba data, the breeding protocols, the complete science of Astrophage. And at the end, you add a personal note: 'There was an alien. His name was Rocky. He was my friend. He saved my life, and I couldn't save his. Remember him.'

interactions.buttonText: Enter the coma pod for the journey home
interactions.resultText: You climb into the coma pod and initiate the sleep sequence. The last thing you see is the stars outside the viewport — alien stars that will soon give way to familiar ones. If you survive the coma. Again.

earth_path_2.title: The Long Sleep
earth_path_2.content:
Four years pass in dreamless sleep. The Hail Mary's autopilot guides the ship across 11.9 light-years of void, decelerating as it approaches Sol.

You wake to a sight that makes your heart stop: Earth. Blue, white, and green, hanging in the viewport like a jewel. The most beautiful thing you've ever seen.

The radio crackles to life. Earth has detected your approach. Messages flood in — from NASA, from the UN, from governments worldwide. You transmit the Taumoeba data. The response is immediate: jubilation. You've brought the cure. Humanity will survive.

interactions.buttonText: Take in the view of Earth
interactions.resultText: The Pacific Ocean stretches below, impossibly vast and blue. Weather systems swirl across the surface. City lights twinkle on the night side. Home. But there's a hollow feeling that won't go away.
The shuttle is on its way. In hours, you'll be on solid ground for the first time in over a decade. A hero's welcome awaits.

earth_arrival.title: Return of the Hero
earth_arrival.content:
Earth orbit. The shuttle docks. Hands reach for you — human hands, the first you've touched in over a decade. You're pulled aboard to cheering, tears, and more camera flashes than you can count.

The Taumoeba deployment begins within weeks. Scientists worldwide breed the organism using your protocols. Within months, Astrophage levels begin to drop. The sun brightens. The ice retreats. Earth is saved.

They give you every award imaginable. You smile and shake hands and say the right things. But every night, you look up at the stars and search for 40 Eridani.

interactions.resultText: Is he still alive? Did his supplies last? You'll never know. The uncertainty is a wound that never heals. You saved your world, but you left your best friend to die seventeen light-years away.
As the celebrations continue, your mind drifts back. Not to the mission, but to the moment you chose to be brave — or at least, to be scared and do it anyway.

rocky_path_1.title: No Regrets
rocky_path_1.content:
The fuel transfer takes three hours. Three hours of watching your only way home drain away. The Hail Mary's gauge drops: 15,000 kg... 10,000... 5,000... 2,000. Enough for life support. Not enough to go anywhere.

Rocky is inconsolable. 'Grace! Stop! You are killing yourself!' You shake your head, watching the numbers drop. 'I'm saving my friend. Earth will get the data by radio. They're smart.'

Something has settled inside your chest — not peace, exactly, but certainty. For the first time since waking up on this ship, you know you're doing the right thing.

Then Rocky makes a proposal that changes everything: instead of staying behind alone, come WITH him to Erid. The Hail Mary can be towed. You won't survive the atmosphere, but his people can build you a habitat.

interactions.resultText: With fuel transfer complete, the Hail Mary is essentially a space station. No interstellar capability. But life support is solid, and you can use Taumoeba to farm Astrophage for power. You could survive for decades. The irony: marooned with unlimited energy.

'I will come back for you,' Rocky says with fierce intensity. 'I save Erid. Then build new ship. Come back for Grace.' You don't argue. You can hear he means it absolutely. But his plan to tow you to Erid is even better. 'Why wait? Come with me now!' 'Rocky, that's insane.' 'Is best kind of idea!'

interactions.buttonText: Transmit Taumoeba data to Earth by radio
interactions.resultText: You broadcast everything: complete Taumoeba genome, breeding protocols, deployment strategies. The signal will take 12 years to reach Earth. They'll have to breed their own Taumoeba, but you've given them the blueprint. It's not a guarantee, but it's hope.

interactions.buttonText: Accept Rocky's offer — journey to Erid together
interactions.resultText: 'Okay, Rocky. Let's go to Erid.' The joy in Rocky's response is a symphony. 'BEST DAY! We go together! I show you everything!'

rocky_path_2.title: Toward Erid
rocky_path_2.content:
The journey to Erid takes years, but you're not alone. Rocky's ship tows the Hail Mary through interstellar space, connected by the xenonite tunnel that has become the most important bridge in history.

You spend the waking hours talking, teaching, planning. Rocky tells you about vast underground cities, ammonia oceans, music used instead of writing. You tell him about pizza, baseball, sunlight through autumn leaves.

'Grace,' Rocky says one day with careful cadence. 'On Erid, when someone gives everything for another... there is no word in your language. Closest is soul-bond. Grace and Rocky have soul-bond now.'

You press your hand against the xenonite wall. Rocky presses back. Some things transcend language.

interactions.resultText: 'Eridian cities are underground. Surface too hot. Big caverns filled with sound — architecture designed for acoustic resonance. Every room sings.' Rocky pauses. 'I will make a room for Grace. Best acoustics. So Grace can hear Eridian music and understand.'

You spend weeks refining the translator, expanding vocabulary, capturing nuance. Rocky helps patiently. By the end, you can have real conversations — jokes, stories, philosophy. Rocky turns out to have a wicked sense of humor.
The ship's vibrations change. 'Grace. We are here. We are at Erid.' Your heart hammers as you rush to the viewport. Through the glass, you see something no human has ever seen before.

erid_arrival.title: A New World
erid_arrival.content:
Erid is magnificent. A roiling sphere of amber and rust, shrouded in dense ammonia clouds that catch 40 Eridani's light in bands of orange and gold. Lightning storms the size of continents crackle across the atmosphere. Hostile, alien, and absolutely beautiful.

The landing is rough but survivable. Immediately, you're surrounded by Eridians — dozens of them, clicking and singing. Rocky emerges and is swallowed by a crowd of his kind. Through the translator, you hear him: 'This is Grace. Grace saved us all.'

The Eridians build you a habitat with astonishing speed — a sealed dome with Earth-normal atmosphere, gravity compensation, even a greenhouse from the Hail Mary's seed bank. The first Earth plants on an alien world.

interactions.resultText: From your habitat, you see vast structures rising from the ground — designed not for sight but for sound. An entire civilization built by beings who navigate by hearing. The gravity is heavier, the atmosphere toxic, the temperature lethal. And yet it's home now. Your home.

interactions.buttonText: Talk to Rocky about being home
interactions.resultText: 'Taumoeba is working!' Rocky practically vibrates. 'Astrophage levels already decreasing!' He softens. 'Grace. You save Erid. Billions alive because of you. They want to say thank you. All of them.' 'Tell them I said you're welcome. And I need a bigger habitat. This one doesn't have a kitchen.'

interactions.buttonText: Reflect on how this all began
interactions.resultText: As you settle into your new life on an alien world, your mind drifts back to where it all started. Not the mission, but the moment you chose to be brave.

flashback_final.title: The Volunteer
flashback_final.content:
The memory surfaces with sudden clarity. Stratt's office. She's told you the crew selection. You're the backup — the guy who trained the real heroes.

Then the call came. One crew member developed a medical condition. They needed your exact expertise. Stratt looked at you with unreadable eyes: 'It has to be you, Grace. No one else can do this.'

You were terrified. You never wanted to be an astronaut. You were a science teacher who liked gravity and breathing without a machine.

But you said yes. Not because you were brave. Because somewhere beneath the fear was a simple truth: if you could help and didn't, you'd never forgive yourself.

That's who you are. A scared man who does the right thing anyway.

interactions.resultText: That frightened schoolteacher who loved his students and his simple life. He'd never believe where he ended up. But the core — the part that couldn't walk away from someone who needed help — that hasn't changed. From saying yes to Stratt, to reaching out to Rocky, to giving up your fuel. The same choice, made by the same scared man, over and over.

interactions.buttonText: Return to the present — to your new life on Erid
interactions.resultText: The memory fades, leaving warmth. You know who you are. And you know you made the right choice.

interactions.buttonText: Return to the present — to Earth
interactions.resultText: The memory fades, but the weight stays. You made your choice. Now you live with it.

hero_ending.title: Good Good Good Friend
hero_ending.content:
Years pass on Erid. Your habitat expands — the Eridians keep improving it, adding rooms, a lab, a greenhouse that would make any botanist weep. You have a life here. Improbable, impossible, wonderful.

But the best part is the school. Rocky helped you build it: a sealed classroom connected to the Eridian education complex by xenonite tunnel. Every morning, young Eridians gather, their small claws tapping with excitement. And you teach them. Science, math, the wonders of the universe. They call you 'Teacher Grace.'

Rocky visits every afternoon. He tells you about engineering projects, Taumoeba progress, council decisions. And sometimes you just sit together in comfortable silence — two friends from different stars, sharing peace.

'Grace,' Rocky says one evening, warm with deep affection. 'You are good good good friend.'

'You are good good good friend too, Rocky.'

And you mean it with everything you have.

— THE END —

You gave up everything to save a friend and his world. In return, you found a home, a purpose, and a friendship that transcended the stars. Dr. Ryland Grace — schoolteacher, reluctant astronaut, hero of two worlds.

earth_ending.title: The Hero of Earth
earth_ending.content:
They give you the Nobel Prize. The Congressional Medal of Honor. Every award humanity can think of. Taumoeba works — within three years, Astrophage levels drop. The sun brightens. Earth is saved.

You return to teaching. Not because you have to — they offered you anything. Director of NASA. Head of the UN Science Council. But you chose a middle school in San Francisco, because that's who you are.

Your students think you're the coolest teacher alive. You have a poster of the Hail Mary on your classroom wall.

But every night, when the sky is clear, you step outside and find 40 Eridani — a faint star, barely visible. You stare until your eyes water. Rocky is either alive or he isn't. You'll never know.

You saved your world. But you left your best friend behind. And some nights, standing under the stars, you wonder if you made the right choice.

— THE END —

You returned to Earth a hero. But the cost follows you like a shadow. Dr. Ryland Grace — brilliant scientist, beloved teacher, savior of Earth — forever haunted by the friend he couldn't save.

death_ending.title: Among the Stars
death_ending.content:
The warning alarms stopped days ago. You turned them off. The Hail Mary's systems fail one by one. Fuel cells depleted. Life support on its last reserves. The temperature drops another degree every hour.

You float in the control room, wrapped in blankets, watching stars through the viewport. Tau Ceti shines steadily — indifferent to your fate. Somewhere, Earth fights for survival. Somewhere, Erid faces extinction. You had the answers. But the cascade of failures — missed opportunities, wrong choices — led here.

Your thoughts drift to Rocky. At the end, it's not Earth you think of. Not the students, not the sunlight. It's a spider-like alien with five eyes and a voice like music, who called you 'friend' and meant it more than anyone ever had.

'Goodbye, Rocky,' you whisper. 'I hope you made it.'

The stars blur. The cold deepens. And Dr. Ryland Grace, schoolteacher from San Francisco, closes his eyes for the last time, seventeen light-years from home.

— THE END —

The mission failed. Without sufficient skill and resourcefulness, the Hail Mary became a tomb. Two worlds face an uncertain future.
